Jobs are ranked relative only to their worth or value to the businesses.

questionText: Early supporters of work specialization saw it as ________.

a good way to increase employee morale
an immoral way to coerce workers into greater productivity

questionText: Early users of work specialization in the early twentieth century found that the practice ultimately resulted in ________.
multipleChoice: higher profits and better employee morale

questionText: Today, managers favor this approach with regard to work specialization.
multipleChoice: All tasks are performed by all employees to promote fairness.
Partners switch jobs every half hour to overcome boredom.
Monotonous tasks are shared by all employees to prevent perceived favoritism.

questionText: Line authority gives a manager the ability to direct the work of ________.

questionText: ________ prevents a single employee from getting conflicting orders from two different superiors.

Both power and authority are rights.

questionText: ________ is the obligation or expectation to perform a duty.

questionText: Which one of the following statements is true?

Power is determined by horizontal position in an organization.

questionText: As represented in a power cone, power is based on ________.

questionText: Today's managers are moving away from formalization and trying to be this.

multipleChoice: ignore rules for the most part
use discretion when it comes to following rules
faithfully follow rules even when it may harm the organization

questionText: The jobs of assembly-line employees are to be changed to allow more tasks to be done by individual workers. This is a reduction in ________.

multipleChoice: Employees are grouped with others who have similar tasks.
Power and authority are widely distributed.
There are cost-saving advantages from specialization.

questionText: What is a weakness of a simple structure?
multipleChoice: Duplication of activities and resources increases costs and reduces efficiency.
Functional specialists become insulated and have little understanding of what other units are doing.
Pursuit of functional goals can cause managers to lose sight of what is best for the overall organization.
Reliance on a single person is risky.

questionText: This is a key characteristic in an organization with a functional structure.
This is a weakness of a functional structure.
multipleChoice: favoring functional goals over organizational goals
favoring organizational goals over functional goals

questionText: Avoiding redundancy is a strength of which structure?
In a ________ structure each business unit has complete autonomy to reach its goals.

multipleChoice: duplication, because a single payroll department could do the job
effectiveness, because separate payroll departments create jobs
efficiency, because separate payroll departments can share methods of operation

questionText: As the number of employees in an organization grows, structure tends to become more ________.

In a team structure, team members ________.
multipleChoice: are subject to decisions made by their supervisors
can influence decisions made by top managers
make decisions and are accountable for their decisions
make decisions only after first checking with management

questionText: All of the following are necessary for successful team structure EXCEPT ________.
multipleChoice: team members with years of management experience
a fair and well-run team-based pay plan

questionText: In a ________, employees are recruited from functional departments to work on a specific project for a limited time period.
In a matrix structure, a group member will typically report to ________.
multipleChoice: both a project manager and functional department head
Group members are fully autonomous in a matrix structure, so they don't report to anyone.

questionText: When a group member in a matrix structure finishes a project, he or she ________.
multipleChoice: returns to his or her functional department
stays with the group to take on a new project
enters a pool of available employees from the entire organization
starts looking for a new job

questionText: By giving employees two direct superiors, a matrix structure violates this key element of organizational design.

multipleChoice: has fairly permanent groups or teams

questionText: In a project structure, when employees finish a project they ________.

A virtual organization is essentially ________ who come together for a particular project.

a team of employees from different departments of a company
a group of top managers and CEOs

questionText: How does a virtual organization save on costs?

by hiring fewer people than they need and making them work much longer hours
by keeping only a small permanent staff for administrative purposes only

questionText: Eric, who is trained as an engineer, is now in a group with production workers and marketing specialists from different departments designing a new product that the company plans to offer. This situation could be described as a(n) ________.

Global competition forces firms to ________.

accept the conventional wisdom of the industry
attract new employees who have special knowledge

questionText: A learning organization requires employees to ________.

share information and collaborate with one another

questionText: All of the following are characteristic of learning organizations EXCEPT ________.

questionText: Which one of the following is NOT a function of planning?
multipleChoice: identifying a strategy for attaining goals
explanation: Settling disputes is not a function of planning, making it the correct response.

questionText: Planning is concerned with ________.
explanation: Planning is concerned with goals or ends, as well as how those goals are reached or means.

questionText: In informal planning, goals are usually ________ shared with others in the organization.
explanation: Informal planning rarely involves recording plans in written form and typically involves sharing plans with few others.

questionText: Informal planning is ________.
explanation: Informal plans are usually nonspecific and lack continuity.

questionText: In formal planning, ________.
multipleChoice: specific goals covering a period of years are defined
to maximize flexibility, specific goals are never spelled out
very broad general goals are developed
goals may be written or unwritten
explanation: Formal planning requires written plans and specific goals.

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a reason for managers to plan?
multipleChoice: to give direction to an organization
explanation: Establishing responsibility for mistakes is not a function of planning.

questionText: Planning gives organizations direction that primarily helps them ________.
multipleChoice: improve their image in the business community
explanation: Direction provides a common path for all employees, helping improve teamwork and coordination.

questionText: Planning gives organizations a way to deal with change that ________.
explanation: Planning helps organizations deal with uncertainty by reducing it.

questionText: Organizations that don't formally plan may be more likely to have ________.
multipleChoice: multiple departments performing the same task
a single department carrying out all company functions
explanation: Formal planning reduces redundancy, so organizations without formal plans may have multiple departments performing the same task.

questionText: One effect of planning on managers is that it forces them to ________.
multipleChoice: anticipate and consider the effect of change
ignore any change that doesn't directly affect them
explanation: Planning requires managers to think systematically about the future and consider the effects of change.

questionText: Managers who fail to plan may ________.
explanation: Managers who fail to plan are likely to be adversely affected by change.

questionText: Which one of the following is a frequently cited criticism of formal planning?
multipleChoice: Plans lock organizations into rigid goals and timetables.
Plans take too long to create.
Plans create resentment within different levels of the organization.
Formal planning works well only for smaller companies.
explanation: One criticism of formal planning is that it can lock organizations into rigid goals and timetables.

questionText: One criticism of formal planning is that it focuses on how to beat the competition rather than how to ________.
multipleChoice: have cordial relationships with the competition
explanation: Critics argue that formal planning can make organizations focus too much on competition rather than new opportunities.

questionText: Failing to discard successful plans from the past is likely to lead to ________.
multipleChoice: more success because conditions are unlikely to change in the future
failure because conditions are likely to change in the future
success because of the high quality of the plans
failure because of the low quality of the plans
explanation: Failing to adapt successful plans to changing conditions can lead to failure as conditions change.

questionText: Studies of performance in organizations that plan have reached ________ with respect to the benefits of formal planning.
explanation: Studies generally conclude that formal planning has positive benefits for organizational performance.

questionText: Studies of planning show that the key to successful planning is to make sure that the plans ________.
In studies in which formal planning did not lead to higher performance, ________ usually the culprit.
multipleChoice: unforeseen events in the environment were

questionText: Formal planning typically leads to which one of the following?

questionText: The first three steps of the strategic management process involve ________ strategies.

multipleChoice: why the company is in business and what it hopes to accomplish

questionText: An external analysis, the second step of the strategic management process, helps identify ________.

the long-term goals of a company

questionText: An internal analysis, the third step of the strategic management process, helps identify ________.
Which term refers to an organization's capital, workers, and patents?
An organization's resources identify ________.
multipleChoice: how the organization gets things done

questionText: An organization's capabilities identify ________.
multipleChoice: assets that the organization can rely on

questionText: Together, an organization's resources and core competencies make up which one of the following?

multipleChoice: strategy for competing in the market

questionText: SWOT analysis combines ________.

a company's philosophy with its ethics

questionText: Once SWOT analysis is complete, managers ________ to address the issues that came up during the analysis.

multipleChoice: finding ways to exploit the organization's strengths
finding ways to protect the organization from external threats
finding ways to rule out existing organizational opportunities
finding ways to correct organizational weaknesses
